target_text: "During the software development process, we implement and exercise practices that assure quality."

Role_Team.Subject: Geography
Role_Team.positionality: As a Product Owner pursuing a master’s in Geography, I approach spatial-economic questions through a pragmatic lens, prioritizing actionable insights for decision-making. My research interest in Economics steers me toward regional development, market accessibility, and place-based policy evaluation, often privileging quantitative, GIS-enabled evidence. I recognize my epistemological assumptions—positivist-leaning and optimization-oriented—which may undervalue lived experience and alternative ontologies. The way questions are framed and how users respond guide my sampling, coding, and model choices, potentially amplifying dominant stakeholder voices. By foregrounding reflexivity and triangulation, I seek to balance efficiency with equity and contextual nuance in interpreting results.

Role_Team.Subject: Statistics
Role_Team.positionality: As a software developer pursuing bachelor’s-level study in statistics, I bring computational problem-solving and data-driven habits to economic inquiry. My research goal is to produce reproducible, statistically rigorous analyses that inform practical economic decisions. I recognize that my cultural background, personal experiences, and a developer’s efficiency mindset can bias variable selection, model choice, and preference for quantifiable outcomes. To mitigate this, I triangulate methods, document assumptions, and invite critique. The question and user responses further shape my framing, operationalization, and interpretation, prompting reflexive checks that align my methods with the study’s context and stakeholders’ perspectives.

Role_Team.Subject: Anthropology
Role_Team.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a master’s-level inquiry, bringing a computational mindset to anthropological questions. Guided by anthropology (QS) and research interests in economics (NSF), I aim to examine how digital infrastructures mediate economic behavior and inequality. My practice is shaped by ethical and societal assumptions—valuing fairness, privacy, open access, and sometimes technological solutionism—which I interrogate through reflexivity. The framing of the Question and the User’s Response directs my attention to certain categories and language, potentially privileging measurable patterns over lived meanings. Consequently, my interpretations may foreground systems, incentives, and data, while I strive to center participant voices and cultural context.

Role_init_codebook.role: Reflexive Software Engineering Researcher — PhD Candidate; QS: Computer Science (Software Engineering); NSF: CISE/IIS; Biases: process-centric, quality-as-culture assumptions

codebook.justification: The phrase [assure quality] signals a value-laden intent, privileging quality as a primary norm rather than a neutral outcome.
Emphasis on [implement and exercise practices] implies disciplined adherence to process maturity within the SDLC.
Use of [we] constructs shared ownership of QA outcomes, foregrounding collaborative responsibility and team accountability.
Referencing the [software development process] centers governance and systemic method over ad hoc practices.

Role_init_codebook.role: Reflective Software Engineering Researcher — Doctoral Candidate; QS: Computer Science & Information Systems; NSF: Software Engineering, Human-Centered Computing; Biases: quality-centric, process-oriented

codebook.justification: The phrase [software development process] foregrounds lifecycle governance, signaling emphasis on procedural control and maturity models.
Use of [implement and exercise] implies intentional enactment and repetition, indicating disciplined routines and capability building.
Reference to [practices that assure quality] signals a purpose-driven QA posture oriented to validation/verification and risk mitigation.
The agentive [we implement] frames quality as a shared, team-owned duty, aligning with socio-technical accountability norms.

Role_init_codebook.role: Doctoral Qualitative Software Engineering Researcher (CISE; socio-technical lens)

codebook.justification: The clause [assure quality] foregrounds quality as the primary value. From a socio-technical SE lens, this normative emphasis shapes prioritization.
References to [software development process] and [practices] imply structured, repeatable methods. My reflexive bias favors reading this as disciplined governance.
The actorial phrasing [we implement and exercise] indicates intentional, proactive action. This frames practitioners as accountable agents in outcomes.
The verb [exercise] connotes repeated practice, not one-off compliance. From a continuous improvement stance, this signals ongoing verification.

Agreed.definition: Positions quality as the explicit purpose of the work, indicated by [assure quality] in the clause [practices that assure quality].
Emphasizes structured lifecycle and methodical execution, signaled by [software development process] and the enactment of defined practices.
Frames quality work as actively owned by the team, shown by the agentive phrasing [we implement] (from [we implement and exercise practices]).

Disagreed.definition: Diverges by inferring a value hierarchy (quality as the primary cultural norm) from [assure quality]; the text states purpose but not necessarily primacy.
Diverges by reading ongoing repetition/continuous improvement into [exercise practices]; the text implies action but not an explicit continuous cadence.
Diverges by inferring anticipatory, preventive intent from [we implement and exercise]; the text shows intentional action but does not specify proactivity.

disagree_explain:
Disagreements center on over-interpretation. The Reflexive SE Researcher tags 'Quality-First Mindset,' inferring a value hierarchy from [assure quality]; the sentence states purpose, not primacy. The Doctoral Qualitative SE Researcher infers 'Continuous Enactment' from [exercise practices], implying ongoing cadence not explicit in the text, and 'Proactive Agency' from [we implement and exercise], reading anticipatory prevention where only intentional action is stated.
Click on the option under Disagreed Items on the left to start the discussion

Closing.definition: Retain this disagreement code because the text only states a purpose—"assure quality"—within "During the software development process..." and does not assert primacy. It guards against over-inference of a "quality-first" value hierarchy, improving coding consistency and precision.

All roles concur that the sentence names actions within a timeframe but lacks explicit cadence markers (e.g., continuous, ongoing, repeatedly). Retaining the code cautions annotators against inferring continuous repetition from 'implement and exercise practices,' improving textual fidelity and consistency.

All roles agree to retain the Proactive Agency disagreement code. The sentence shows intentional action—'we implement and exercise practices that assure quality'—but contains no explicit anticipatory or preventive markers. Retaining the code prevents over-inference of proactivity and clarifies that proactivity must be textually signaled.

Codebook.definition: Positions quality as the explicit purpose of the work, indicated by [assure quality] in the clause [practices that assure quality].
Emphasizes structured lifecycle and methodical execution, signaled by [software development process] and the enactment of defined practices.
Frames quality work as actively owned by the team, shown by the agentive phrasing [we implement] (from [we implement and exercise practices]).
